text: Continuing with this section. I'm a bit confused by how "-" relates to the other bitwise operators. First, it's not clear to me how is it a bitwise operator and not an aritmetic operator. But then in the footnote exercises, its clear that it can be used as a set operation. Like A\B = A - (A&B), which can be easily seen as A without the intersection of A and B.

text: I wonder what's your opinion on Kernighan & Ritchie. It's definitely not _modern_ C (the last edition is not even about C99), but it's probably a kinder, gentler introduction to C than Modern C. (Some people would insist that the right way to approach C and pointers would be to start with assembly, but we don't have the time for such a course.)

text:
I think that the answer to your question is that you can pretend that `-` is a bitwise operation when there's no carry, i.e. the truth table looks like this (LHS in the rows, RHS in the columns):

``` -|| 0| 1
==||==|==
 0|| 0|NA
--||--|--
 1|| 1| 0```
The `&` in the right-hand side guarantees that there won't be any carry, letting you use `-` instead of `a & ~b` (set difference can be computed as intersection with complement).

text: Is that when A >  B (in number)?

elements.text: Is that when A >  B (in number)?

text: Well... when every bit of A is ≥ than the corresponding bit of B. So it works with 0b1111 - 0b1000 but doesn't work with 0b1000 - 0b0111.

elements.text: Well... when every bit of A is ≥ than the corresponding bit of B. So it works with 0b1111 - 0b1000 but doesn't work with 0b1000 - 0b0111.
